channel.title: Reading .dat files?
channel.description:
I'm not sure if this is the right section, I'm just assuming it has something to do with Java because it has something to do with Runescape :s
The .dat files Runescape creates for accounts.. Are they readable? There are files for each of my accounts, then a "random.dat".
I uploaded both incase you're not sure what I'm talking about. (had to .rar, mitb doesn't like .dat's :rolleyes:)
Edit: Reading a guide at the moment, looks promising :)
Edit2: Alright. I've come to the conclusion that all dat files are for different programs, it isn't a file that can just be opened in one program. So these ones from Jagex, can they only be read by Jagex? Or can we somehow read them? X;

item.title: Reading .dat files?
item.dc:creator: @xeez xeez`
item.description:
@xeez wrote:

[quote=“oksuper_, post:24, topic:295486”][quote author=xeez` link=topic=391487.msg2916064#msg2916064 date=1250450522]

[quote author=oksuper_ link=topic=391487.msg2916061#msg2916061 date=1250450026]

It doesn’t ‘redownload’ the ‘cache’… it requests entries it needs in the ‘cache’ from the update server.
[/quote]I assume it requests it through the so-called “JAGGRAB” strings?

This is how we know you’re not new. Incorrect, the client doesn’t even use JAGGRAB. You’d only think it did if you had previous experience with older clients, therefore blowing your cover. Cold?
[/quote]It appeared in the 317 client build which I retrieved from a private server.

Yes, because you ARE from a private server background. Just give up, you’re excuses are getting boring.[/quote]Or maybe because those clients are (semi) re-factored?

Read full topic

[/quote]I assume it requests it through the so-called “JAGGRAB” strings?

This is how we know you’re not new. Incorrect, the client doesn’t even use JAGGRAB. You’d only think it did if you had previous experience with older clients, therefore blowing your cover. Cold?
[/quote]It appeared in the 317 client build which I retrieved from a private server.[/quote]

Yes, because you ARE from a private server background. Just give up, you’re excuses are getting boring.

item.dc:creator: @Jython super_
item.description:
@Jython wrote:

[quote=“xeez`, post:21, topic:295486”][quote author=oksuper_ link=topic=391487.msg2916051#msg2916051 date=1250449325]
It doesn’t ‘redownload’ the ‘cache’… it requests entries it needs in the ‘cache’ from the update server.
[/quote]I assume it requests it through the so-called “JAGGRAB” strings?[/quote]

This is how we know you’re not new. Incorrect, the client doesn’t even use JAGGRAB. You’d only think it did if you had previous experience with older clients, therefore blowing your cover. Cold?

Read full topic

It doesn’t ‘redownload’ the ‘cache’… it requests entries it needs in the ‘cache’ from the update server.

item.title: Reading .dat files?
item.dc:creator: @xeez xeez`
item.description:
@xeez wrote:

[quote=“Taharok, post:18, topic:295486”][quote author=xeez` link=topic=391487.msg2916045#msg2916045 date=1250448952]
Among the “bounds of the sandbox”, file interaction is not included. How is it that the client interacts with the cache, when running in unsigned mode?
[/quote]

It doesn’t. It downloads the chunks it needs from the Jagex server on-demand, hence why it takes 50x longer to startup the unsigned client than the signed one.[/quote]Oh, I see. So even if one has the cache stored on his/her computer, if the client is ran in unsigned mode, it will re-download the cache.

Thanks

Read full topic

item.title: Reading .dat files?
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

xeez`:

Among the “bounds of the sandbox”, file interaction is not included. How is it that the client interacts with the cache, when running in unsigned mode?

It doesn’t. It downloads the chunks it needs from the Jagex server on-demand, hence why it takes 50x longer to startup the unsigned client than the signed one.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @xeez xeez`
item.description:

Among the “bounds of the sandbox”, file interaction is not included. How is it that the client interacts with the cache, when running in unsigned mode?

item.title: Reading .dat files?
item.dc:creator: @frank frank_
item.description:
@frank wrote:

yes, the client can run with no security privileges, as to how? what do you mean? it just does what it can within the bounds of the sandbox

Read full topic

item.title: Reading .dat files?
item.dc:creator: @xeez xeez`
item.description:
@xeez wrote:

[quote=“oksuper_, post:14, topic:295486”][quote author=xeez` link=topic=391487.msg2915737#msg2915737 date=1250390672]
Oh, wow. Many thanks for the explanation; it clears up various things. The reason I hadn’t found it is because I was exploring through the “unsigned client”, or the client without the “loader signlink”.

That brings me to the question, how is it that even when running the client in an unsigned mode, the loader can run signed? I would assume the loader uses some sort of “sandbox” method, but even then, the client would not have access to files such as the cache. Perhaps you can enlighten me with another explanation.

By the way, what is the purpose of having the player’s ID stored within the cache?

In the code snippet you pasted, I don’t see the use of any “random.dat”. Unless of course, it refers to the “RandomAccessFile” object.

Again I say, thanks for the explanation. Perhaps you have an email or such which I can contact you?
[/quote]

random.dat is read via a RandomAccessFile. It is also the player’s UID, which is a sort of identifier for that computer’s client session. It is sent in the login packet. The loader is running signed because it is signed… you have to click ‘Allow’ :[/quote]No, no. You’ve misunderstood me. I meant to say, even when running the client in unsigned mode (meaning you didn’t click “allow” or something of that sort :P), how is it that the loader can still run in a signed-environment. Because from what I understand, the runescape client has the ability to run in an unsigned environment.

I understand that it is the player’s unique identifier, but what I don’t understand is why there is a need to store it? Does runescape limit one connection per computer?

Read full topic

item.title: Reading .dat files?
item.dc:creator: @Jython super_
item.description:
@Jython wrote:

[quote=“xeez`, post:13, topic:295486”]Oh, wow. Many thanks for the explanation; it clears up various things. The reason I hadn’t found it is because I was exploring through the “unsigned client”, or the client without the “loader signlink”.

That brings me to the question, how is it that even when running the client in an unsigned mode, the loader can run signed? I would assume the loader uses some sort of “sandbox” method, but even then, the client would not have access to files such as the cache. Perhaps you can enlighten me with another explanation.

By the way, what is the purpose of having the player’s ID stored within the cache?

In the code snippet you pasted, I don’t see the use of any “random.dat”. Unless of course, it refers to the “RandomAccessFile” object.

Again I say, thanks for the explanation. Perhaps you have an email or such which I can contact you?[/quote]

random.dat is read via a RandomAccessFile. It is also the player’s UID, which is a sort of identifier for that computer’s client session. It is sent in the login packet. The loader is running signed because it is signed… you have to click ‘Allow’ :\

Read full topic

item.title: Reading .dat files?
item.dc:creator: @xeez xeez`
item.description:
@xeez wrote:

Oh, wow. Many thanks for the explanation; it clears up various things. The reason I hadn’t found it is because I was exploring through the “unsigned client”, or the client without the “loader signlink”.

That brings me to the question, how is it that even when running the client in an unsigned mode, the loader can run signed? I would assume the loader uses some sort of “sandbox” method, but even then, the client would not have access to files such as the cache. Perhaps you can enlighten me with another explanation.

By the way, what is the purpose of having the player’s ID stored within the cache?

In the code snippet you pasted, I don’t see the use of any “random.dat”. Unless of course, it refers to the “RandomAccessFile” object.

Again I say, thanks for the explanation. Perhaps you have an email or such which I can contact you?

Read full topic

item.title: Reading .dat files?
item.dc:creator: @BAsh BAsh
item.description:
@BAsh wrote:

oksuper_:

The client then uses this signlink. But whats that do? Simple, the signlink from the loader is still privileged, so it lets the client request privileged actions through it. Signlink is just a service that links the client’s unsigned environment with the loader’s signed environment, which should be pretty easily deduced from the name.

The security manager goes all the way up the stack so if there is a frame which is unsigned, the entire stack is considered unsigned. You just need one unsigned frame and you have unsigned privileges. That means you need to pass instructions back using primitive data types or hard code everything into the launcher. If it is hard coded then it seems wrong to say that it is an interface for the client. Assuming thats right: Signlink seems a bit pointless in the signed client. I think its still there because they cbf to remove it and it provides a common API to the underlying file system. Maybe you can enlighten me.

Read full topic

item.title: Reading .dat files?
item.dc:creator: @Jython super_
item.description:
@Jython wrote:

Mopman:

Didn’t random.dat just have your uid in it?

I don’t know what it is, so hell it must be encrypted!

@xeez`: Maybe you should take a look into the signlink class. This is a nifty class JAGeX use that is used in both the loader and the client. The loader’s version is run in a privileged environment, and the client’s is unfortunately not. What the loader does is load the client, and pass its signlink to the client. The client then uses this signlink. But whats that do? Simple, the signlink from the loader is still privileged, so it lets the client request privileged actions through it. Signlink is just a service that links the client’s unsigned environment with the loader’s signed environment, which should be pretty easily deduced from the name. Anyway, back on subject, the signlink class has a method with a local String[] variable that contains a list of possible cache home directories. Visit each and find your very own, and if you’ve ever played runescape, there should be a random.dat inside the folder (the cache folder is named after the game that uses it, e.g. runescape, arcanists, etc and is a child of a folder following the format of .jagex_store_<store#>, or .file_store_<store#>; this folder is in turn a child of the cache home :p). This contains your client session UID, which is sent during login.

Edit:
Now with code!

item.title: Reading .dat files?
item.dc:creator: @bloodrayne bloodrayne
item.description:
@bloodrayne wrote:

Maybe, I never really knew about the folder until I saw a 103mb .jagex_cache_32 in meh c:

xeez`, please navigate to your main drive my going to start, My Computer, and the C: drive, or whatever your main filesystem drive is. Look for .file_store_32, or .jagex_store_32.

Read full topic

item.title: Reading .dat files?
item.dc:creator: @xeez xeez`
item.description:
@xeez wrote:

[quote=“Mopman, post:8, topic:295486”]Didn’t random.dat just have your uid in it? :/[/quote]Excuse my ignorance, but what client build includes the “random.dat” file? I’ve searched the current client, and have yet to find it.

Read full topic

item.title: Reading .dat files?
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

Didn’t random.dat just have your uid in it?

Read full topic

item.title: Reading .dat files?
item.dc:creator: @xeez xeez`
item.description:
@xeez wrote:

[quote=“oksuper_, post:6, topic:295486”][quote author=xeez` link=topic=391487.msg2915619#msg2915619 date=1250385456]
If it’s the runescape client that reads it or writes it, you can deobfuscate the client and search for the creation/reading of the file and reverse the encryption.
[/quote]
I like how you automatically assume it’s encrypted.
So, the ‘cache’ bare file system is encrypted?
The player UID is encrypted?

/facepalm[/quote]I have never come across any “random.dat” file in the current runescape clients, but by the sounds of it, I would assume it follows a sequential protocol or encryption. If so, he would have to be able to reverse it (in case of encryption) or simply know how to read the custom file’s protocol.

Read full topic

item.title: Reading .dat files?
item.dc:creator: @Jython super_
item.description:
@Jython wrote:

xeez`:

If it’s the runescape client that reads it or writes it, you can deobfuscate the client and search for the creation/reading of the file and reverse the encryption.

I like how you automatically assume it’s encrypted.
So, the ‘cache’ bare file system is encrypted?
The player UID is encrypted?

/facepalm

item.title: Reading .dat files?
item.dc:creator: @bloodrayne bloodrayne
item.description:
@bloodrayne wrote:

I’m not sure if this is the right section, I’m just assuming it has something to do with Java because it has something to do with Runescape :s

The .dat files Runescape creates for accounts… Are they readable? There are files for each of my accounts, then a “random.dat”.

I uploaded both incase you’re not sure what I’m talking about. (had to .rar, mitb doesn’t like .dat’s :rolleyes:)

Edit: Reading a guide at the moment, looks promising

Edit2: Alright. I’ve come to the conclusion that all dat files are for different programs, it isn’t a file that can just be opened in one program. So these ones from Jagex, can they only be read by Jagex? Or can we somehow read them? X;

Read full topic
